text: Þórhallur Bjarnarson (2 December 1855 15 December 1916) was an Icelandic prelate and politician who served as a member of parliament between 1894 and 1899 and from 1902 to 1908. He was also the sixth Bishop of Iceland from 1908 until 1916. ==Biography== Bjarnarson was born in Laufás near Eyjafjörður, the son of the Reverend Björns Halldórsson and his wife Sigríður Einarsdóttir. He graduated from the School of Applied Sciences in 1877 and graduated with theology from the University of Copenhagen in 1883 . He was ordained a priest on March 18, 1884 and was appointed pastor at Reykholt. That same year he was also appointed Dean of the Borgarfjarðar Deanery. On March 19, 1885, he was appointed pastor of Akureyri however on August 28 he became a lecturer at the Prestaskólar (Seminary) and later its director in 1894."Þórhallur Bjarnarson", Ismus. Retrieved on 22 July 2019. He was also the Member of Parliament for Borgarfjörður between 1894-1900 and 1902-1908, first as an independent and then as a member of the Home Rule Party. He served as President of the Lower House between 1897 and 1899. He also was also a member of the City Council of Reykjavik between 1888 and 1906. On September 19, 1908 he was appointed Bishop of Iceland to succeed the retiring Hallgrímur Sveinsson. He was consecrated by Sveinsson on October 4, 1908. He served as bishop until his death. ==Family== Þórhallur lived longest in Laufás near Laufásvegur in Reykjavik. His wife was Valgerður Jónsdóttir (27 January 1863 - 23 January 1913). They had 4 children, including Tryggvi Þórhallsson who became Prime Minister of Iceland in 1927. His other 3 children were Svava, Björn and Dóra who married Ásgeir Ásgeirsson and who became President of Iceland in 1952."Þórhallur Bjarnarson", Althingi. Retrieved on 22 July 2019. == References == Category:1855 births Category:1916 deaths Þórhallur Bjarnarson Category:20th-century Lutheran bishops
title: Þórhallur Bjarnarson
